alert.note: Alert for Polk (Minnesota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks (Northeastern North Dakota and Northwestern Minnesota)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued April 15 at 10:43AM CDT until further notice by NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Grand Forks ND has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in North Dakota...Minnesota... Red River of the North at East Grand Forks affecting Grand Forks and Polk Counties. Red River of the North at Halstad affecting Norman and Traill Counties. Red River of the North at Oslo affecting Walsh, Grand Forks, Marshall and Polk Counties. Sheyenne River near Kindred affecting Cass and Richland Counties. Maple River near Mapleton (South of I-94) affecting Cass County. Maple River near Enderlin affecting Cass and Ransom Counties. Pembina River at Neche affecting Pembina County. ...Forecast flooding changed from Minor to Moderate severity for the following rivers in Minnesota... Red Lake River at Crookston affecting Polk County. .Snowmelt river flooding to continue. Rate of rise and ultimate crest is uncertain due to rate of ongoing snowmelt runoff and possible rain and colder temperatures in the forecast. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. ...FLOOD WARNING FOR SNOWMELT REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Red Lake River at Crookston. * WHEN...Until further notice. * IMPACTS...At 20.0 feet, MODERATE FLOOD STAGE. EOC activated if advised by EOC Committee. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:15 AM CDT Saturday the stage was 17.9 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 10:15 AM CDT Saturday was 17.9 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 20.5 feet tomorrow morning. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. &&
info.instruction: Safety message - Turn around, don`t drown. Don`t travel through flooded areas. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely.
